cards.question: In what ways are human activities harming the planet?
cards.answerHtml: Relentless deforestation, ever-growing piles of waste and energy-hungry industry are steadily pushing the planet to its limits.

cards.question: Why do many people move to big cities?
cards.answerHtml: For many, cities promise social mobility, a sense of possibility and a lifestyle that feels plugged into the modern world.

cards.question: How are phones changing our daily life?
cards.answerHtml: Smartphones have turned quiet moments into scrolling time, made attention a scarce resource and blurred the line between work and rest.

cards.question: Why is workâ€“life balance hard today?
cards.answerHtml: In many jobs, the expectation is to be always available, which turns home into an extension of the office rather than a place to switch off.

cards.question: How does globalisation change local culture?
cards.answerHtml: Globalisation can replace local colour with a familiar mix of chain stores and streaming platforms, yet it also creates new hybrid identities.

cards.question: What makes a good teacher?
cards.answerHtml: A good teacher does more than deliver content: they spark curiosity, challenge lazy thinking and stay human in the process.

cards.question: Why do many people feel stressed?
cards.answerHtml: Many of us live in a loop of endless notifications, fragile finances and the quiet feeling that we are always behind.

cards.question: How does money shape our choices?
cards.answerHtml: Money quietly sets the limits of what feels possible, steering everything from the jobs we accept to the risks we feel able to take.

cards.question: Why do people like travelling abroad?
cards.answerHtml: Travel offers the chance to step outside our bubble, see how other societies organise life and return home with a slightly wider lens.

cards.question: What can young people do to improve the future?
cards.answerHtml: Young people can ask awkward questions, organise calmly but firmly and refuse to treat problems as â€œtoo bigâ€.
